image.altText: A man sits on a pile of tyres.

props.synopsis: Two Darwin businesses have been left with tonnes of tyres and a massive clean-up bill after falling victim to a tyre dumping scheme that has impacted people across Australia.

title.children: The 'nightmare' scam that illegally dumped 50 tonnes of old tyres in a yard

image.altText: a honey mango cut open and sliced into cubes with another half behind.

props.synopsis: Northern Territory mangoes can freely flow into Western Australia after the regions agreed on a new fruit fly management protocol, weeks out from the NT mango harvest.

title.children: Territory mangoes to flow back into WA as agreement reached on fruit fly

image.altText: A man in a button-up shirt and jeans, walking towards the courthouse while holding his wife's hand.

props.synopsis: A key witness faces allegations that he was a cocaine dealer among explosive claims aired in the trial of Netflix star and celebrity crocodile wrangler Matt Wright.

title.children: 'Something wasn't right': Allegations heard against Matt Wright so far

image.altText: Emissions from a smoke stack illustrating carbon pollution

props.synopsis: Environment groups and researchers say that a troubling trend of weakening environmental protections in Western Australia is now being mirrored in the Northern Territory, following the release of a new emissions policy this week.Â

title.children: Environment groups say a worrying WA environment trend is taking place in the NT

image.altText: A police man stands between a police vehicle and residential fence.

props.synopsis: A 62-year-old man has died in police custody during the execution of a search warrant at a home in Palmerston, south of Darwin.

title.children: Police investigating man's death in custody south of Darwin

image.altText: A black and white headshot of Douglas Crabbe.

props.synopsis: In 1983, Douglas Crabbe slammed his semi-trailer into the side of a Central Australian pub, killing five people. Survivors say he should never be released from jail.

title.children: 'Never-ending nightmare': Call for Uluru mass murderer to remain in jail

image.altText: A large poster saying 'Justice for Kumanjayi White' laid on the lawn, with other protest posters and people surrounding.

props.synopsis: NT police have provided an update on their investigation into the Warlpiri man's death in custody in Alice Springs, saying it is at an "advanced state" but still waiting on a forensic pathology report.

title.children: Police say investigation into Kumanjayi White's death at 'advanced state'

image.altText: Russian President Vladimir Putin waves from behind a lectern

props.synopsis: Vladimir Putin does not have the same goals as the other players in his game and the longer the various iterations of meetings and summits and phone calls go on, the more advantage he gains, writes Emily Clark.Â

title.children: Trump may have been outplayed in Alaska, but let's remember Putin is the problem

image.altText: An Australian rugby union player dives full-length to score a try near the corner flag in a Test match against South Africa.

props.synopsis: The Wallabies recover from a 22-point deficit to shock the two-time defending world champion Springboks 38-22 in a first win at altitude in 62 years, as the All Blacks also win away over Argentina.

title.children: Coach 'blown away' in Wallabies' crazy comeback over Springboks

image.altText: A woman holds balls of rice to the camera.

props.synopsis: Amid severe shortages and pressure from Donald Trump's "reciprocal tariffs", Japan is under unprecedented pressure to eat more foreign rice. Here's why that's controversial.

title.children: Japan's rice crisis sparks debate over food security and identity

image.altText: A graphic of a house being dropped on a conveyor belt.

props.synopsis: From early colonial settlers to the post-war construction boom, prefabricated and modular housing has a long history in Australia. Can factory-built homes fix our housing woes and help the climate?

title.children: Modular homes can be built quickly and cheaply. But there's an image problem

image.altText: dreame-x40

props.synopsis: A major Chinese robot vacuum maker's smartphone app has a critical security flaw leaving it susceptible to leaking user data and credentials if targeted by hackers.

title.children: Own a Dreame robot vacuum? Don't use public WiFi to control it

image.altText: An Indian man wearing a green shirt with his left arm in a sling, sitting on a grey couch.

props.synopsis: Saurabh Anand feared he may have to leave Australia after a shocking machete attack saw him nearly lose his hand. However, the government has granted him a visa on compassionate grounds.

title.children: Victim of 'cowardly' alleged attack granted fresh Australian visa

image.altText: Ornate snake door handles next to sign 'Fun Time Pony'.

props.synopsis: Patrons at a Canberra nightclub experience breathing difficulties along with eye and skin irritation after a woman allegedly releases capsicum spray inside the venue.

title.children: Nightclub evacuated after woman allegedly releases capsicum spray

image.altText: Star rugby league player Payne Haas (middle) stands with a Samoa executive and national coach holding a Samoan flag.

props.synopsis: In a blow to Australia's hopes of defending its Rugby League World Cup title next year, star forward Payne Haas confirms he is switching his allegiance to Samoa.

title.children: Payne Haas reveals moment he decided to switch from Kangaroos to Samoa

image.altText: Alex Lloyd leans his chin on his hand, resting on the top of his guitar.

props.synopsis: In 2001, Alex Lloyd broke through with his massive hit Amazing, a song that led to the best and then the worst time of his life. Now he's getting his life back on track.

title.children: The 'evil drug' and court case that almost broke Alex Lloyd

image.altText: a large group of tents in gaza city sit on top of rubble and in front of destroyed buildings

props.synopsis: Gaza residents will be provided with tents and other shelter equipment starting from Sunday ahead of relocating them from combat zones to "safe" ones in the south of the enclave, the Israeli military said.

title.children: Israeli military prepares to relocate residents to southern Gaza

image.altText: Lauren Jackson arrives for the Sport Australia Hall of Fame, posing on the red carpet in a black evening dress

props.synopsis: For some it's about money, for others it's regaining fame or relevance. For basketball star Lauren Jackson the decision to step out of retirement had nothing to do with either reason, and instead was all down to a happy accident. Getting back to super star fitness level was no easy task though.

title.children: Money, pressure and fame: Why elite athletes step out of retirement

image.altText: A naked man and woman lean on a fence.

props.synopsis: When you think of nudism, you might picture postcard-perfect beaches or serene forests. But what about swathes of rugged Queensland bush, where the only neighbours are cattle herds and coal mines?

title.children: Thongs the only requirement at this bush weekender turned nudist haven

image.altText: A graphic of books and age classifications such as G, PG, M and MA 15+ restricted.

props.synopsis: The growing influence of BookTok, BookTube and Bookstagram has a researcher concerned about the content young people are engaging with, and they are calling for an industry-wide book rating classification system.Â

title.children: Alarm sounded over domestic violence themes in books popular with teens

image.altText: two girls stand with homemade bilby masks on their faces.

props.synopsis: Inspired by trips to Wild Desert park, outback kids hit the stage to retell the ecological comeback story of bilbies in the Corner Country of New South Wales.

title.children: Important lessons as outback kids turn into bilbies and quolls

image.altText: A young couple sitting in a shed, smiling at the camera.

props.synopsis: It's becoming easier for Australian households to live off-grid, but how much could it cost and what are the benefits?

title.children: The reasons why there's a renewed interest in off-grid living

image.altText: Smiling grey-haired man and woman standing outside the Royal Victoria Hotel with their dog looking up at them.

props.synopsis: Jan and Chris Ferguson are at the centre of Beltana's latest revival story, reopening a historic pub after decades.

title.children: Historic outback pub pouring beers again after 60 years

image.altText: A young woman wearing an ankle-length skirt and blouse roller skating in the middle of a city street.

props.synopsis: In 1977, the ABC interviewed a 21-year-old rollerskater during a police crackdown on public nuisance, in a video that has since gone viral. Five decades later, we've tracked her down â and she still skates.

title.children: Melbourne rollerskating icon famous again â half a century later

image.altText: Man shakes hands with a robotic prosthetic

props.synopsis: Australia's decline in productivity, and falling business investment, has policymakers worried. It's why they're meeting in Canberra this week.Â

title.children: What is productivity? If we can do more with less effort, we all benefit

image.altText: A man and his dog

props.synopsis: After applying to keep a dog when NSW tenancy laws changed in May, Casey Munro says he was told his border collie was likely to cause more damage than his bond covered.

title.children: Tenant denied a dog by landlord has decision scrapped under new laws

image.altText: A map showing the affected area after an earthquake in Sulawesi, Indonesia

props.synopsis: Indonesian officials say a magnitude-6 earthquake has struck the Indonesian island of Sulawesi, east of Borneo.Â

title.children: Magnitude-6 earthquake strikes Indonesian island of Sulawesi

image.altText: Salmon pens and a boat in waters near a coastline.

props.synopsis: The Tasmanian government will halt marine expansion of the salmon industry in local waterways while an independent review is ordered, an announcement that comes as the minority government prepares to face a hostile return to parliament this week.

title.children: Tasmanian salmon farming expansion plans on pause as Liberals order review

image.altText: Three men cycle on a red dirt road surrounded by green paddocks.

props.synopsis: The lure of red dirt roads lined by fields of green and gold draws thousands of "gravel grinders" to WA as off-bitumen cycling events grow in popularity worldwide.Â

title.children: Scenic country towns capitalise on gravel cycling boom

image.altText: A paramedic standing alongside a parked ambulance outside a hospital.

props.synopsis: Western Australiaâs ailing health system has once again been in the spotlight this week, but the remedy to its problems remains elusive.

title.children: WA's 'world class' health system is ailing, and no one seems to have the answers

image.altText: Bindi Irwin smiling in a hospital bed

props.synopsis: It took 13 years, 51 endometriosis lesions, a cyst, two surgeries and a hernia before she was able to start healing. Now Bindi Irwin wants to break the stigma surrounding women's health on a global scale.

title.children: The power and pain of Bindi Irwin's endometriosis journey

image.altText: Australian batter Glenn Maxwell brandishes his bat and roars in triumph in mid-pitch after hitting the winning runs in a T20I.

props.synopsis: A chaotic beamer from Kagiso Rabada proves costly for South Africa as Australia posts a thrilling two-wicket T20I win over South Africa with one ball to spare.

title.children: Maxwell the T20I hero in Cairns as Aussies win with one ball to spare

image.altText: Tom Gleeson on the set of Hard Quiz gesturing behind him with a serious expression.

props.synopsis: Ah, back again I see. I do admire your courage for giving it another go â¦ just kidding, I never feel that way.

title.children: Put your trivia know-how to the test. I dare you
